quizzes.textContent:
[h1]CSS Syntax[/h1]

CSS is composed of style rules that the browser interprets and then applies to the corresponding elements in your document. 
A style rule has three parts: [b]selector[/b], [b]property[/b], and [b]value[/b]. 

For example, the headline color can be defined as: [code format="css" codeId="503"]h1 { color: orange; }[/code]
[b]Where:[/b] [img id="2584" width="100%"]
The selector points to the HTML element you want to style.
[note]The declaration block contains one or more declarations, separated by semicolons.
Each declaration includes a property name and a value, separated by a colon.[/note]

quizzes.question: Rearrange the code to create a valid CSS style rule:

quizzes.textContent:
[h1]id and class Selectors [/h1] [b]id selectors[/b] allow you to style an HTML element that has an [b]id [/b]attribute, regardless of their position in the document tree. Here is an example of an id selector: [b]The HTML:[/b] [code format="html" ]

This paragraph is in the intro section.

This paragraph is not in the intro section.

[/code] [b]The CSS:[/b] [code format="css" codeId="504"]#intro { color: white; background-color: gray; }[/code] [note]To select an element with a specific id, use a hash character, and then follow it with the id of the element.[/note] [b]Result:[/b] [img id="2585" width="100%"] [b]Class selectors[/b] work in a similar way. The major difference is that IDs can only be applied once per page, while classes can be used as many times on a page as needed. In the example below, both paragraphs having the class "first" will be affected by the CSS: [b]The HTML: [/b] [code format="html" ]

This is a paragraph

This is the second paragraph.

This is not in the intro section

The second paragraph is not in the intro section.

[/code] [b]The CSS:[/b] [code format="css" codeId="505"].first {font-size: 200%;}[/code] [note]To select elements with a specific class, use a period character, followed by the name of the class. Do [b]NOT [/b]start a class or id name with a number![/note]

[h1]Descendant Selectors[/h1] These selectors are used to select elements that are descendants of another element. When selecting levels, you can select as many levels deep as you need to. For example, to target only elements in the first paragraph of the "intro" section: [b]The HTML:[/b] [code format="html" ]

This is a paragraph.

This is the second paragraph.

This is not in the intro section.

The second paragraph is not in the intro section.

[/code] [b]The CSS: [/b] [code format="css" codeId="506"]#intro .first em { color: pink; background-color:gray; }[/code] As a result, only the elements selected will be affected:[img id="2992" width="100%"]
